Watch now as I completely geek out. From when I rediscovered the show as it entered its second season, I've always been pretty fond of urlLink Buffy: The Vampire Slayer . Much like the other shows I tend to watch, it's a show that is driven primarily by the writing. The writing is always pretty sharp. Primarily, I've always enjoyed the comedy aspects of the series first and foremost. Some of the funny is inspired genius. A lot of the comedic references made by the characters are completely unrealistic in terms of the characters that say them, but it's always such a urlLink money shot , that as a viewer its remarkably easy to forgive. Yet, for the last two-three seasons, I've developed a lack of interest, and even a minor disdain for the show. It's only been while rewatching the episodes again on DVD that I've begun to realise why I stopped caring. What's gotten me thinking about this is an article published on the Salon website, which you can read by clicking urlLink HERE . The article lay the blame primarily on the introduction of the character of Spike into the show. Thinking about it, it's become apparent to me that this is only really a surface analysis of the problem with the show. It isn't so much Spike that's the issue, it was the shift of sensibilities in the series that resulted in the show losing its appeal (in my eyes), and it was this shift that allowed Spike to become a prominant player in the show. When Buffy first began, we met our heroes in high school. Note that I said heroes. The show has never just been about Buffy. She's the focus of the show, and it's seen through her eyes, but the show is ultimately about her gang of friends. Buffy. Xander. Willow. The shows heart has lay with this trio. As the seasons progressed, the show used Buffy's vampire killing/slayer lifestyle as a metaphor for the stages one goes through in ones teenage years and growing into maturity. And for the most part, it was successful. It's been the shows shift away from that which has been the problem for me. The first three seasons were set in Sunnydale High School, where the week-to-week episodes dealt with a different metaphor. One episode dealt with some students being posessed by some Hyennas, a metaphor for students teaming together with a pack mentality. Another episode The first major shift away from the characters and manor in which the themes of the show were depicted changed with the outing of Willow as a lesbian. Part of the shows appeal was that the trio were seen, or at least felt, as outsiders at high school. Earshot, an episode at the end of season three (just before their urlLink graduation ), featured Buffy telling a fellow student that everyone in high school feels alone and distant from the same pain everyone feels. The acknowledgement of this fact by Buffy signals a change in the characters evolution which continues into the next season as they enter College. Throughout the first episode of season four, we see Willow settle into a comfortable life at College. No longer is she the outsider. Instead, she is now being accepted by the college society, a place that respects education and intelligence. Willow represents the change that a person feels when they do leave the cocoon of high school and find that their former awkward self can in fact be an asset in the larger world. Yet this change and evolution in character is perverted by the change midseason where she forms a romantic and sexual relationship with another female student. Willows acceptance at University is ignored, and instead focus shifts to her new lifestyle choice. Again, Willow is made to be an outsider in the show. The lone homosexual character in a series populated with urlLink straight characters. It was mid season five that created the biggest shift in sensibilities. The shift that knocked the entire show off its axis. The death of Joyce Summers, Buffy's mother. Buffy's growth and maturity as a person was always shaped by her life as a slayer. And so, in mid-season five, it seemed that the writers decided that Buffy needed to be seen as developing into her own person. An independent adult. And so, to do this, they killed her mother Joyce. The show which had always served as a metaphor for an average teenage girl was now altered by an event that is rare for most teenage girls of that age, the death of their parent(s). If the show were to remain true to its initial gameplan, the death should not have been urlLink Joyce Summers , but instead Giles, Buffy's 'Watcher'. Giles job had been to guide Buffy in her role as a vampire slayer. To kill Giles would be an opportunity to symbolise Buffy's development from teenager to young adult. The loss of the mentor guiding her through life, thereby forcing her to take responsibility for her own path. I understand from a writers point of view why they chose to bump Joyce off. She had always been a dull character, while Giles was hella cool. Yet, the loss of Joyce never felt true to the spirit of the show. Since then, any metaphorical development of the characters has just felt forced and a little false. It's a shame, because it used to be a hell of a ride.

So the television executive says to the other television executive "You know, I'd really like to do a weekly Shakespeare television series" "That's an excellent idea" *obviously this second executive works for the first. "We need a show that will appeal to the young demographic, so I was considering Romeo & Juliet. It'll have two young leads. A romantic plot. We don't have to let them sleep together straight away, we can build the URST up over the first season". "But sir, we work for Fox". "Shit. I hadn't thought about that". "Maybe we can throw in lots of cool editing like jump cuts". "Will that be enough....wait....sex. We'll add lots of sex.....I'm having a brainwave....Juliets father can work in pornography....he'll be a porn baron. We can be edgy and cutting edge. We'll be proactive and compete with HBO." "Shall I get Jerry Bruckheimer on the phone?" "Yes. Immediately". And so began the creative process for the new Fox series urlLink SKIN . So, what's the deal with it? Featuring two star-crossed virginal lovers, with 90210 style good-looks, and tragic 90210 style acting, Skin focuses on the romance between the son of a District Attorney trying to make a political name for himself by taking down a billion-dollar porn king. Yay for contrivance, because it just so happens that the son has just started a relationship with the porn kings daughter. In this post-Sopranos TV environment, the US nets are busy trying to emulate the success by developing edgier adult drama. Witness NBC's attempts urlLink KINGPIN . Comedian Drew Carey mentioned in his Dirty Beer and Jokes that in America only the wealthy are allowed to see pornography and violence. If you can afford cable television, you can view these acts nightly in your own home. Yet, those without a disposable income are only able to watch the free-to-air television shows, where sex and violence is minimal. This show is a testiment to that very belief. Despite all the references to pornography, the show features a complete lack of any nudity at all. Not to say there aren't naked people in it. The show has two-scenes that are supposed to titilate the viewer. But instead, the insistance on covering any glimpse of nuaghtiness completely nullifies it. Anyone who knows me is probably just gunning for the pervert factor to my criticism here, but I feel my point is legitimate. They need to be more clever about the way they're executing this supposedly cutting edge television. If they want to make the show sexy, they need to be smarter about the way they try to seduce the audience. Glimpses of women covering their nipples just isn't really that sexy. It's very bland. Who's In It? Well, pretty much no one of note other than Ron Silver, of Heat Vision and Jack fame. The pilot itself was directed by urlLink Russel Malcahy of whom directed a few Duran Duran videos and the movie Highlander. The show is produced by Jerry "I make movies with quick edits" Bruckheimer. So, what happens in the crucial first episode? Not a heck of a lot. Boy meets girl. Boy falls in love with girl. Fathers wage war against each other. A strip club is blown up. It sounds much more interesting than it is. But is it any good? Not really, no. There's something slightly watchable about it, but mostly, its bland and horrible. It's horrible that gems like F-Troop will stay in a vault somewhere, while shit like this stinks up the airways. In summary, if Skin was like F-Troop, the Nielson ratings would soar.

Earlier today I was told that I'm only interested in softcock TV shows. Probably true. That said, it seems that there are a heck of a lot of TV pilots currenty hitting the Internet at the moment. As a TV nerd with a broadband connection, I feel its my duty to take a look at some of these gems. And non-gems. And by non-gems, I mean anything by Stephen Bochco. Today I took a gander at the pilot for Mister Sterling. The show isn't new. In fact, I think it was used as a mid-season replacement earlier this year and wasn't picked up for the new season. That said, it still hasn't aired in Australia yet, so I figured I'd take a peek. What's It About? Mister Sterling centres on the son of a former senator who is chosen to take over a seat in the senate by a senator who died. So, yes, it's very heavy on the US politics. The show itself could easily be described as what The West Wing would have been like if Aaron Spelling produced it and decided to tone down the sex a little. Mister Sterling was created and produced by urlLink Lawrence O'Donnell , a former writer on the West Wing. It's a modern day Mister Smith Goes To Washington. The only difference is that Mister Smith goes To Washington never guest starred porn queen Jenna Jameson. Much to its own detriment, I've always felt. Who's In It? The cast is filled with a ton of those actors that cause you to spend most of the time trying to work out "where have I seen that dude before?". The show is led by urlLink Josh Brolin , son of Mister Barbara Streisand: James Brolin. While Josh can never follow in his fathers footsteps by appearing in something as great as urlLink Pensacola: Wings of Gold . Supporting players involve the former TV-version of Jeff Spicoli urlLink Dean Cameron , urlLink Harris Yulin , and former father figure in Boy Meets World urlLink William Russ . So, What happens In That Crucial First Episode? As you'd expect, Mister Sterling comes to Washington. he meets a few of the wrong people, but he's a smart guy under that all-American facade and eventually works out who he can trust. In the pilot, as Sterling settles into his first day, he mistakenly tells a reporter that he doesn't belong to the Democrat party. A problem in that the party hold a very tight position of power in the Senate. Just one more Republican in the senate means that they get to take power. So what does the Republican party do to keep power? They resort to the very thing that makes America great: bribery. But is It Any Good? I quite liked it, but then, I quite like The West Wing, which has been accused of being liberal softcock television. In many ways, this is to the West Wing what shows like High Incident, or The District are to something like NYPD Blue. It's a heck of a lot more featherweight in terms of quality, but it does strive high. The cast don't really click properly in the first episode, but they all have potential. It's just a shame that the show aspires to be higher brow than it ever will be.

It's the end of the world as we know it, and I feel fine. Well, actually, that's not true. It's more of a hopeful nervous trepidation. For the last four years on television (three actually, in Australia), hidden amongst the trite aussie dramas, home renovation shows, and multiple Law and Order clones, was a television show that did things a little differently. I like to call it close to perfection, others call it The West Wing. But alas, the greatness of the show is very close to its end. After a very public series of disputes between urlLink Warner Bros and urlLink Aaron Sorkin , Sorkin has opted to leave the series that he created and had a hand in writing the majority of its episodes. So, what now for the show? With a new writing team, and a showrunner, The West Wing is going to be facing some major changes. I actually have a lot of faith in urlLink John Wells . He developed and produced ER during its first two seasons, which were the high point of the show before it slipped into soap-ish melodrama and implausability. Plus he (or in the very least his secretary) replied to a letter I wrote to him back in ER's early days. And that was mighty nice of them. The simple fact is that despite the fact he's a good showrunner, he doesn't have Sorkin writing for the show. The West Wing is very much Aaron Sorkin. I've never met the guy, but I do believe in the auteur-principle, and if you watch enough of an artists work, you begin to learn quite a lot about who they are and what they bring to the table. Sorkins scripts brought with him not only the standard political storylines that one might expect from a show such as this, but he also brought with him a very specific tone to his dramatic and comedic moments. Honestly, it's hard to really clarify what the tone is, and its very easy to simply classify it as being Sorkin-esque, but ultimately its simply that his characters are highly intelligent in their thoughts, dialogue, and actions. Sure, they do come off often as being pretentious as hell with no realisation of just how they are, but that is what gives them there charm in a way. It is rare to find a character in a Sorkin series of minimal intelligence. The plots on The West Wing next year will probably continue in similar fashion to the way they have all along. Yet, the show will not be the same. The show will at times be sexier and probably more exciting for the most part, but it will miss the moments that are the most crucial to the show. These are the moments where the characters have something thoughtful to say or do, and when they do this, television doesn't become any finer than this. Until Sorkin gets his next show up and running, television is going to be missing a great deal of mind and soul. Enjoy the last episodes of season four as they air on channel Nine over the next few weeks and appreciate them for their intelligence.

People often criticise the US television stations for buying the rights to British comedy series and remaking them. But the way I see it, it could be worse. Consider Are You Being Served In Australia. Doesn't seem so bad, does it? The problem is that when you're taking a comedy from one country to another, the comedy stylings just don't quite work. Note the current US remake of the show Coupling. And it's a shame, because the remake almost works. Almost. So, what's the deal? Well, it's exactly the same as the UK version. There's a few alterations to the script, but most of the dialogue and scenes from the first episode of the UK version are redone with US accents. The script is even credited to the writer of the UK version, Stephen Moffat. And, honestly, some of the rewrites actually work much better than the original episode. For those of you who don't know, the show revolves around a couple starting a relationship, their two best friends, and their ex-partners. It's just like Friends, except with lots of smut. Oh, and it's funny. Who's In It? Basically, its a big bunch of unknowns. The only cast member I recognised was Rena Sofer (who had a semi-recurring role in Ed). The show runner is former Cheers writer Phoef Sutton. It's a shame that the damn thing wasn't casted better as that's where the fault lies completely. Rena delivers her lines satisfactrily, but the other actors have no idea what to do. Their hands gesture wildly, and its almost like watching a sitcom from the early 50's where it was treated akin to a stage show. It causes the series to come off highly ameteurish. So, what happens in the crucial first episode? Well, we meet everyone. Steve meets Susan, and the rest all sort of interact in the background. It culminates in a resturant where they all watch Susan show them her right breast. But is it any good? Not really. I quite like the UK series for all of its faults, which I think has to do with a reasonably charismatic cast. The US casting has been horrible. NBC are looking at the series to work as a replacement for Friends when that concludes its run at the end of the next season. Part of the success of Friends was that the ensemble all clicked together relatively well. The pilot is worth a watch if only for a lesson in how to almost succeed in remaking a series.

George (A female....because it's cool to give girls boys names in TV shows) believes that its best not to become too interested in things, because it will save from being disappointed. She's directionless in life with trouble connecting to her family and former friends. A ton of great funny moments and a heck of a lot of script development. George dies. She finds out she's a ghost, and in turn a grim reaper. Then there's fun and hi-jinks as she learns how to be a Reaper, while also making some contact with her family. There's a beautiful moment where she rearranges some magnet letters on the family fridge to contact her mother from the afterlife.....it's certainly not a sacchrine moment. But is it any good? It's certainly the most promising new show I've seen in a few years. It works as a bit of a mixture of urlLink Ghost World meets urlLink Six Feet Under , but brings its own vibe to the mix. It's a hoot.

After the wholesomy goodness of Mister Sterling, the dirty nature of the very lame Skin, and the tragically even lamer Fearless, there's finally a pilot thats made its way onto my hard drive that has delivered the goods. Karen Sisco. A few years ago, there were two things that rocked my cotton white socks. The movie Out of Sight, and the heavenly beauty that is Carla Gugino. This television series merges them both together in a cacophony of television goodness. So, What's the deal? Karen Sisco is a television series based on the character from the movie Out of Sight. The film starred Jennifer Lopez in the only good film she's ever made. The focus is split in the series between her work as a US Marshall, her relationship with her father (formally a US Marshall), and her relationships with other men. All three are always entwined in some manner. Who's In It? Well, there's Carla Gugino, who is not only a babe, but has also starred in the first season of Spin City, the Pauly Shore modern day classic Son In-Law, and the well-directed, but ultimately crappy flick Snake Eyes. She's ultra-fab as a leading lady, and works a treat as Sisco. Her father is played by Robert Forester who I dug in Jackie Brown. And then there's the guest cast for the first episode featuring Jake Busey and Xander Berkely. Mostly, the casting is pretty top-notch. Out of Sights writer Scott Frank is also on board as a consulting producer, with the show being produced by Danny DeVito's production company Jersey Television. So, what happens in the crucial first episode? The show is in an odd position in that the events of the film can be presumed to have taken place. So, the pilot is more about re-establishing the characters and the way they involve themselves in her life. The episode is also given a plot with Karen seeking out an escaped prisoner of whom she inadvertantly helps escape. But is it any good? Very much so. It's a show that the first 4-5 episodes will either make or break, but its stylish and reasonably involving. The escaped prisoner storyline didn't do a huge amount for me, but everything else held together pretty darn well. It's off to a very strong start.

Horror has a new name, and that name is Everybody Loves Raymond. By itself, it's not completely horrible. It's certainly much more watchable than a lot of other family-centred sitcoms on the air (primarily I'm thinking about the abysmal Reba, but there's certainly a lot of other examples). What irks me is how channel 10 have adopted Raymond as the jewel in its comedy crown. For a while, it was being aired no less than seven times a week with a mix of both new and old episodes in various timeslots. Two words. One hyphen: Over-kill. The show can actually be entertaining, there's the occasional inspired, funny moment. It just simply isn't that good. In no way does it have the watchability of a show like Seinfeld, or Frasier. Both shows tend to be repeated pretty frequently lately, and I'm still yet to get sick of either despite how often I've seen the episodes. Everybody Loves Raymond does have two strengths. The first is Peter Boyle. Honestly, Boyle isn't great in this, but generally, Boyle always delivers the comedy and dramatic chops in anything he appears in. Just take a look at his Emmy-Award winning performance in The X-Files episode Clyde Bruckmans Final Repose, or his gig as the monster in Young Frankenstein. The dude is gold. The second strength of the show is Brad Garrett, who has more or less become the focus of the show as Raymonds brother Robert. The guy plays his lethargic, wounded butterfly character like no other ever could. The guy simply screams for you to pay attention to him with just his standard frowning glance. Currently, however, Garrett is fighting with the producers of the show over a pay dispute. He hasn't turned up to work for two weeks running as a ploy to get paid at a similar scale to his fellow cast-members. This morning I found this article online: As the squabbles over salary continue between Brad Garrett and CBS, Garrett has decided not to report to the set of EVERYBODY LOVES RAYMOND for another week. Yesterday, RAYMOND producer Phil Rosenthal decided to give Garrett the finger by giving co-stars Patricia Heaton, Peter Boyle and Doris Roberts a cut of the producing pie for the show. Each actor will get half a percentage point ownership in the show, which means they will profit about $5 to 7 million dollars. Producers have already cut Garrett out of the season premiere already and will likely do so for the second episode. Source: Hollywood Reporter That's just madness. The show is in what they declare to be the final season. Just pay the guy some cash and put up with him on set for a couple of months. He's really the only reason the show has been occasionally watchable. He might be an arsehole, but he's certainly bringing a lot more of the funny than the succubus Patricia Heaton. The woman needs a cross and a stake ASAP. I say, pay the dude, they'll have a better show for it in the long run.

In his book High Fidelity, Nick Hornby asked whether depression leads to pop music, or whether pop music causes depression. The same can be said for current affairs shows. Is the world really in a sorry state of affairs, or does it just seem that way because Today Tonight have informed us that it is? Every time I tune into Today Tonight, and its channel Nine partner-in-crime A Current Affair, the sheer tabloid nature of the shows spirals me into such a fit of anger that I'm honestly concerned I may turn big, green, and start throwing tanks around. The stories shown never give two-sides to an arguement, and are instead designed to do nothing more than anger the viewer against whatever group or organization the show is attacking. Last night (12/8/03) in Queensland, the local Today Tonight edition aired a story about a building the government were leasing, but not using, for a large rental fee each month. Naomi Robson, one of Satans minions, as well as being the host of the show, introduced the story, told the viewers how outrageous the issue is, featured a two-second video grab of some white guy behind a desk telling us its outrageous, continued to rattle off some "facts", and then showed another one-line grab of the guy behind the desk. Whatever happened to legitimate journalism? I'm not saying the government are in the right with the leasing of the building, but during this entire "story", the only person giving us any facts was the host of the show. There was no video footage of anything really backing the story up. There was next-to-no attribution given, and worst of all, there was no opportunity given for the supposed offenders to comment. Even if a government spokesperson decided not to comment, the least the story should have done is told us that the government would not comment. The thing that irritates me the most is that despite the declining intelligence of the "reporting", large segments of the population still regard each story as the complete truth. Even those that know how bullshit the stories are continue to watch. And why? Because the only alternative is Neighbours.

I'd fallen in love. Sure, I never realised it at the time, but as I looked at its glow, I knew we'd be together for the rest of our lives. Or so I'd thought. Instead, The Wonder Years simply disappeared from my life. In the early 90's, Channel 10, in a stroke of programming genius, aired The Wonder Years every afternoon at, what I remember to be, 4:30pm. I watched the show daily watching Kevin Arnold growing up with me, and as the episodes passed, growing older than me. As the episodes progressed, the lessons Kevin learned became more adult than I was prepared for at that age. I may not have understood them properly at the time, but the messages still came through to an extent. This evening, I found myself watching the show on cable, where everything old is new again. Two things struck me while watching it. Firstly, the show is damn entertaining. The writing, direction, and even the acting was all remarkably sincere. It may not have rung completely true, but its as close as TV of this nature is likely to get. Secondly, it's a shame that kids these days aren't getting the opportunity to watch this show. I realise the show is occasionally aired by Channel 7 on saturday mornings/afternoons, but its somehow not quite the same. There aren't many dramatic shows made that kids can watch and actually relate to. Most dramatic scripted shows are either fantasy-based, or simply don't cover subjects that the viewers will likely experience in their own lives. Props to The Wonder Years for actually managing to do this.

It hasn't really come as much of a suprise, but newspapers nationwide this morning have been reporting that Channel Nine have cancelled urlLink Micallef Tonight . Quite a shame really. I haven't seen the show at all for a few weeks, but it was quite easily one of the better variety talk shows on TV. Micallef has a great offbeat comedic voice, and its a little sad to see that it's been silenced. One has to question why Micallef was poached by Channel Nine to begin with. It was obvious watching the show that they were trying desperately to tone down the exact same comedic style that Micallef is known for and was hired to bring to the show. He was lumped with horrid guests, of whom were marketed to be the focus-point of the show. Instead of actually tailoring the show to Micallefs strengths (ie sketches and other written bits), they instead tried to foist even blander guests upon him. Nine's last failure in doing a late-night variety show was Rove. Ten dusted it off and actually gave the show some support and confidence, and the thing has taken off. One could almost be caught wondering if a similar thing could happen for a performer with comedic talent. Ironically, the news of Micallefs cancellation comes at the same time as several shows being cut from the ABC. The most notable one being the childrens current affairs series Behind The News. The worlds biggest nob, our communications minister Richard Alston attacked the ABC for cancelling shows like BTN while lighter comedy series like The Glasshouse is still on the air. Alston is under the impression that commercial networks are catering product for the same audience that watch lighter-hearted fare on the ABC. The cancellation of former ABC-comedian Micallef from Channel 9 just proves how wrong that belief is. At least it lasted longer than urlLink The Mick Molloy Show .

The film The American president had its President utter the line "This is a serious job for serious people". The films writer Aaron Sorkin seems to have always kept this in mind over the four seasons in which he'd written The West Wing. His characters were very much serious people, working in a serious job. Despie this, the characters were also human. Despite their approach to their work, they were given life through what was also a harmonic song of vibrancy. Each line of dialogue sparkled and shone as a beacon of life through an industry that tends to treat dialogue purely perfunctory. The season premiere of the fifth season of the show aired in the US this week. It's the first episode to be aired that was written without the guidance of Sorkin. Ever since I heard about the departure of Sorkin, I feared that the show would join the pantheon of other great television shows that would go on to die. And if this first episode is anything to go by, then my fears appear to have been confirmed. It is a serious job, for serious people. But the people are also intelligent and smart as a whip, whatever the heck that means. This, however, has fallen by the wayside. These former smart characters are not only not saying much of intelligence, but they're also not even acting seriously about their job. Witness Josh, the Deputy Chief of Staff of The White House sitting in a room lounging with his assistant, and fellow senior staffer Toby. Both of them have important voices in the White House, yet neither are involved in the events surrounding them, but are instead voicing their concerns for the viewing audience. The West Wing characters are akin to a husk of their former selves. Sapped of their intelligence and their life, it's almost as if they are now without a soul. They're cast off to wander the TV desert of other lifeless serious characters on television. The storylines may continue to grow and develop, but that has never been what The West Wing was about. Farewell The West Wing. Welcome to the world of mediocrity.

Anyhow, I just found this article online from urlLink The Age and figured I'd share it with you all....enjoy! Fifty years on, cinema in the sedan is enjoying a resurgence, writes Suzanne Carbone. Drive-ins have come a long way since the days of crackly speakers hung on the car window. But some things never change: people are still trying to sneak in via the car boot. Cars with sagging boots don't often get past the ticket box, but the audacity is part of the thrill, as is romance under the stars on a first date to remember - even if the film is a distant memory. It is 50 years since construction began on Australia's first drive-in, the Burwood Skyline. From the boom times of 320 nationwide, only 25 remain, with four in Victoria at Coburg, Dandenong, Dromana and Shepparton. But the industry has fought back since the graveyard era that started in 1984, when the video recorder and the sell-off of drive-in land looked like spelling its death. Dandenong's Lunar Drive-in opened its third screen on Thursday last week to cater for the sprawling outer suburbs and their appetite for Choc-Tops and action films. Lunar director and drive-in buff David Kilderry, his brother Matthew and friend Anthony Madigan set out last year on their Lunar mission, to recreate the glory days of the 47-year-old Dandenong Drive-in after an 18-year closure. Last Saturday night, girls in hipster jeans mingled in the snack bar with young women in pyjamas and moccasins. Outside, vintage Fords parked alongside the panel vans and family sedans. Snuggled up in the back of their station wagon with a mattress, doona and pillows were Shanagh Lavery and Nick Burnham, who liked the comfort and privacy of their car. "You can relax," Ms Lavery said, "and bring a pizza." Sally and Ron McBride brought Laura, 11, and Brittany, seven, to the early-bird session at 6.30pm to see Finding Nemo, and the double feature at 8.45pm, Legally Blonde 2 and Bruce Almighty. Mrs McBride said three movies for $41 was great value, but even better was the absence of annoying neighbours. The drive-in craze began in the United States in June 1933 when Richard Hollingshead opened the world's first at Camden, New Jersey. It has been the focus of popular culture, immortalised in the films Grease and American Graffiti, and in the opening credits of the TV cartoon series The Flintstones. Victoria had 60 drive-ins during the peak era in the 1960s and 1970s when EH Holdens and Chargers reigned. Drive-in names conveyed the romance of the outdoors - the Maribyrnong Sunset, Moe Fairsky, Bairnsdale Moondale and Echuca River-Vu. The 38-year-old Coburg Drive-in has kept the romance alive with a retro theme that lures the 1950s car enthusiasts with hairstyles to match. Many groovers prefer the old window speakers over FM stereo radio, which was first introduced at Dromana in the late 1980s. Everyone has a drive-in story, such as the time a fire broke out behind the Coburg screen during The Towering Inferno and patrons thought the fire engines racing through the car park were a publicity stunt related to the film. Mr Kilderry was mesmerised by the very big screen while growing up, seeing the Coburg Drive-in from his home in Reservoir. He said the industry's enduring charm was nostalgia meets retro-chic. "The drive-in combines two icons of the 20th century, the motion picture and the automobile," Mr Kilderry said, adding that it offered the ultimate escape on wheels. "That is what the cinema has over in-home entertainment. The TV is just a piece of furniture." Mr Kilderry said the drive-in's appeal was timeless: for the oldies it was nostalgic and for the youngsters it was novel. It offered value for money and freedom - patrons pay by the car load and dress as they like (yes, tracky dacks and pyjamas). It is a group experience that can be personalised and, unlike indoor cinemas, you can adjust the sound and the temperature. As the saying goes: "At the drive-in you can smoke, drink and slash your own seats." But there's more. When R-rated sex films were hugely successful between 1971 and 1981, they drove away families but attracted a new clientele, with reports that a prostitute set up shop in the Wantirna Drive-in snack bar. Videos, suburban multiplex cinemas and the DVD have failed to extinguish the lure of the drive-in. John Iozzi, the managing director of Village Cinemas Australia, which runs Coburg, said it continued to be popular for its "novelty meets nostalgia" experience. "For a lot of people, they are reliving their teen and early adult years," Mr Iozzi said. It is hoped a retro-chic theme will lure buffs to the temporary Moonlight Drive-in at the Queen Victoria Market car park from next Friday to November 16, to be run by the organisers of the Moonlight Cinema at the Royal Botanic Gardens. Others plan to reopen the Warragul Twilite Drive-in on weekends.

In my soulless eyes, there's nothing better than a well made dramatic television series. Witness my love for current shows like The West Wing, 24, the Law & Order shows (not that I see any of them as often as I probably should), etc. As a viewer you have to commit to them a little, but generally they can be far more rewarding than most movies these days. The thing is, there's also a string of television shows that want to be the high quality shows, but simply will never quite cut the mustard. If the popular shows are the Fonzie's, these second stringer shows are the Chachi's. They're okay and might arouse the attention of Joannie Cunningham, but they'll never score highly with a Leathers Tuscardeo. Last night saw the emmergence of another Chachi, the new action-drama The Agency. So, what's the deal with it? The 90's showed that smart action drama's can be done weekly on a television budget. The best example of this is The X-Files which featured a ton of impressive special effects and stunt work on a smallish budget. Basically, a lot of corners were cut, but they covered it up to look as classy as possible. The trick is to have a director and writers good enough to hide the cut corners. The Agency has so many corners, it's boxed itself in. After having watched the first episode, I'm still at a slight loss as to what the exact premise of the series is, other than it's about CIA Agents trying to stop stuff every week. Which isn't really a bad place to start. The problem lies with the fact that all of the characters are replica's of no-specific characters you've seen in tons of shows like this before, the plot aims far higher than it should be, and the dialogue is pretty poorly handled. But it is a first episode, and the cast and concept is good enough to maybe eventually get cooking. Who's In It? Well, there's that dude who played Billy in Ally McBeal, Gil Bellows. He makes a fine lead in a drama series like this, and with the knowledge that The Agency didn't make it past a second season, I wouldn't mind horribly watching him star in something of a little higher quality. Other notable characters are played by ER's Gloria Reuben, Ronny Cox (who you've seen in a whole slew of movies including his classic role as Richard "Dick" Jones in Robocop), and the second movie April O'Neil: Paige Turco (also seen in the short-lived American Gothic). Former Hardy Boy Shaun Cassidy is one of the executive producers of the series, with another being German director Wolfgang Peterson (U-Boat). So, what happens in the crucial first episode? They try to stop a visiting Fidel Castro from being assasinated during a trip to the United Nations building in New York. Watch for horrible production values as Fidel Castro arrives to an enthusiastic reception of ten people waving flags. Also watch for high-up CIA officials who laugh when they learn that past attempts to assasinate Castro involved giving him explosive cigars (as most Modern History high school students across the globe are fully aware). But is it any good? I'd watch it again, but only in the same way that I might find myself watching an episode of Get Smart if I stumble upon it. It would be interesting to see if it improves at all, especially with the minor cast shake-up mid season. In summary, the CIA are only looking out for what's best for everyone. Now let us hold hands and sing folk songs....but only with tight camera shots so that the audience doesn't realise that the set we're on is not by a campfire, but instead on an old Dr Quinn Medicine Woman set.

With the announcement that the ABC was going to bring back Dr Who weeknights (starting mid September), nerds across the nation (after a quick daliance with some Kleenex) began to wonder if this might pave the way for another screening of the other ABC staple, The Goodies. Thanks to the marvelous glory of DVD, this question isn't such an issue anymore. 8 "Delicious" episodes are now available for you to own on two shiny discs. When I popped in the discs the other day, I was astounded by two notable things. The first was the picture quality. Never have I seen the show look as amazingly crisp as it does in this collection. At one point in the rather poor commentary for "The Goodies and The Beanstalk", its remarked that the picture quality is even better than it was originally in real life. The second thing that astounded me was the level of special effects that were used in the show. Not only was there a heck of a lot of effects, but its obvious that a great deal of effort had been spent in their creation. The episode "Kitty Kong" is filled to the brim with effects shots. Sure, the effects are pretty poor looking compared to todays SFX, they won't exactly have you marvel or quake with fear as The Goodies face off against the awesome might of the giant kitten, but considering it was the very early 70's, its damn impressive. K-Mart this week were offering the disc set at $39, while most stores were charging at least $47. It makes it a pricey disc set to buy on a whim. I'd hesitated at first, but the novelty value of it was too great and I caved. Thankfully so, as its been one of the most enjoyable DVD's I've spun in the last few years. A lot of the jokes may be a little dated and tired now, but the comedy is just so genuine, and there's enough absurdist brilliance in each episode to make it more than worth your while. If you have even a mild fondness for the show, it's well worth every cent (but shop around).

I felt completely shagged. It'd been a hard days work. My evening was spent going out to dinner and seeing a movie. Ordinarily, dinner + movie = good evening out, but I was so tuckered out that I simply wanted to crash. So, you can understand the predicament I was in when trying to fall asleep. The TV was on. Sleep timer set. Me in bed. The FOXTEL remote on the floor, three metres away. And on television.... "My Mother The Car". Now, I'd never seen this show before. I was vaguely aware of the concept, but considered it to be such an oddity from yesteryear that I never expected to have to endure the pain that is "My Mother The Car". Let us just think about the title of the show. "My Mother The Car". What television executive in their right mind would even consider green-lighting a show like that? It's madness. A show with a talking horse. Sure. Why not? It's a little goofy, but it's a fun concept. A talking car? Sure. Why not? Knight Rider was a pretty cool show, and that car spoke. And what a car it was. Heck, K.I.T.T. was as close to a ladies man as a car can get. But a talking car that is in fact the reincarnated mother of the star of the show? The Freudian aspects to the concept are more than enough to wierd me out. Dave Crabtree (played by Jerry van Dyke) is not only living his life in a separate bed to his wife, but also one day discovers that his mother has been reincarnated as a 1928 Porter automobile. And what more, he keeps it a secret from his wife. If that isn't an unhealthy mother-son relationship, I'm not sure what is. Makes me quite concerned about Dave's relationship with his father, and any subsequent actions he may take if his father takes the old car out for a ride. Thankfully the show was cancelled pretty quickly. What troubles me is that the show is still being aired on television. Surely after it's cancellation, someone should have had the good sense to place the film it was shot on into a rocket and fire it at the sun. Why didn't the UN step in and organize for that to happen? Television should be an enriching experience. Or at least one that allows you to enjoy the snappy banter of five retired women living fulfilling sex-lives in Florida. This whole experience has left me feeling rather dirty.

Foxtel's Digital Vision Coming at an estimated cost of over AUD$600 million, the digitalisation of Foxtel is well underway. NDS Group has been engaged to provide conditional access and an electronic programme guide, Pace will take a lead role in supplying set-top boxes and middleware will come from Open TV. Pace and NDS also have involvement in the development of PVR technology for the pay-TV provider, while on the network side, Telstra is installing cable head-ends and a new digital play-out centre is under construction in the Sydney suburb of North Ryde. Speaking at this year's Australian Broadcasting Authority Conference in Canberra, Patrick Delany, Director of Digital for Foxtel, said the launch of Foxtel Digital in early 2004 is not about technology, it's about entertainment. "It's about building a platform upon which entertainment and people making choices can thrive," he says. "You will not need a new TV set for Foxtel Digital. We will simply turn up and swap your box if you're an existing subscriber, install your return path and you're off. "There will be better quality pictures and sound. It will be 'DVD-lite' in the crispness of the picture and Dolby sound. We will have over 100 channels at launch which is a larger number of channels compared to our current 47." The tool to navigate through this expanded universe of channels is the NDS-developed electronic programme guide which will be based in that used by Foxtel sister network, BskyB of the UK. According to Delany, "This guide will allow subscribers to really have a look and see what is on any television channel on Foxtel for up to eight days in advance. "You'll be able to categorise by channel, you'll be able to categorise by programme start time and then sift through movies and different genres. So, it's an excellent navigational tool and one that is absolutely essential when you have so many channels." Also essential to the Foxtel Digital offering will be the 'Box Office', a bouquet of movie channels that will offer first-run, time delayed and near video on demand (NVOD) programming, including pay per view. "The Box Office will be very important to Foxtel," says Delany, "especially in the context of the DVD revolution that is going on. There's a tendency to think that one technology or one product has to always over-ride another. I think that many products can live within their own zone and be good for the area that they specialise in. We think Foxtel Box Office will fit a very wanting part of the market where you'll be able to choose the movie that you want to watch without having to drive to the video store for a similar price and with a similar quality that DVD has. I don't think for a second that it's going to mean the end of DVDs or the end of videos, but we hope that we will take a little bit of the market." Added to this offering will be a variety of interactive capabilities which, Delany says, will concentrate mainly on the context of the pictures. He maintains the interactivity will be all about entertainment, not transactions. The interactive offering will, again, be similar to that currently running on the UK's BskyB. These include games, messaging, multi-view sport with access to match data and highlights, as well as a mini EPG of news channels and near news on demand. As is the case with the Foxtel Box Office, this will be achieved by aggregating several channels of vision into the one application. Once the digital roll-out is completed, Foxtel hopes to crown its offering with the introduction of hard disk-based Personal Video Recorders (or PVRs). The Foxtel PVR will be very similar to the NDS XTV. The XTV allows authorized viewers to: access both live and stored content, watch one program while recording another; record two programs at once; fast forward, rewind, pause for live and recorded content; order a program directly from the operator's EPG; automatically schedule updates to avoid missing favourite programs; control which content to record or pause; record a single program or multiple episodes of a series. "We think that PVRs are a little bit like Holden's Monaro," says Delany. "It's an aspirational tool that we'll be introducing after launch and it really does give the ultimate in choice and control for our subscribers. It allows easy storage of your favourite shows. They'll be no more of this joke about the eight year old being able to set the timer on the video better than an adult." The final element of Foxtel's digital conversion, under ACCC conditions, is allowing newcomers and established broadcasters access to the platform (at a price). "We've offered the [terrestrial] broadcasters the opportunity to participate in terms of retransmission," says Delany. "The outcome that we think will be desirable from that is that it will allow consumers and subscribers to access both over-the-air and subscription channels through our EPG with ease. "Our subscribers will have more choices and we think that adds up to a better value equation. It means there'll be new ways in which they can engage with channels and we think it puts them closer to ultimate control over what they want to watch, when they want to watch it."

The bastard step-child that Shelley Long never wanted is finally drawing towards the end. Frasier Crane, after eleven years is leaving the building. A couple of days ago, NBC announced that this season would in fact be the final year for Frasier. While it will not receive the same level of attention as the Friends finale, I'm confident that Frasier will go out with class, and with jokes that are actually funny. Frasier has always been an oddball sitcom on commercial television in the US. While it's never afraid to take the show in low-brow directions, the show has very rarely pandered to the lowest common denominator. The show isn't necessarily the smartest on TV, but it certainly doesn't stop the characters from thinking they may be. Frasier has spent 11 years on TV creating loved characters out of pompous and arrogant upper-class snobs. By celebrating their bombasity, as well as bringing them down a few pegs each time, it's created characters that one actually feels could be real. Unlike the paper thin characters that seem to inhabit almost every other sitcom. It was during the middle of CHEERS' run that Frasier Crane first entered our lives. Originally entering the show as the fiance and love interest of Shelley Long's Diane Chambers character, Frasier was quickly embraced by the shows writers with his role expanding from just a short stint on the show to becomming a regular. With this new character in the show, the balance of the core of the show (the relationship between bar owner Sam Malone and Diane Chambers) was shifted quite considerably. Rumour has it that it was the impact that Frasier had on Cheers that caused Shelley Long to leave the series halfway through its run. While the show was never quite as funny in its later seasons, the show still continued with high ratings So Cheers begat Frasier, but what now for the Cheers/Frasier universe? There's talk of a spin-off series involving Frasiers brother Niles, which seems like a logical and potentially interesting place to take a new series. Certainly a character that will work better than with the proposed Friends spin-off 'Joey'. It'll be a shame to see Frasier off the air, but all good things come to an end. And yet the end of Will & Grace just can't come soon enough.

Usually I'm annoyed by a reviewer who chooses not to even sit through whatever it is that they're watching. Surely if you're going to give your opinion on something, you should at least have engaged in that of which you are reviewing. And so, I was hesitant to review the new lesbian drama The L Word from Showtime. And that's when I remembered I don't actually have anyone who reads this blog. Hence, I care not for the lack of any percieved integrity. The L Word isn't necessary 'love". The opening credits push forth this notion with a plethora of different L words. Lust, love, leperacy, lamentation, lamington, lupus, lesbian. It's this last L word that the show seems to be preoccupied by. It's a lesbian drama. The term lesbian drama is offensive. There's more to a person or an artwork than just their sexuality. The problem is that The L Word falls into the same trap as the majority of supposedly progressive TV shows and movies that attempt to depict characters with queer and lesbian sexualities: there's just nothing else to it. It's a drama series where two-dimensional women have relationships with women, discuss their relationships with women, and have intercourse with women. Any show that has me bored watching lesbians is criminal. But that's what I was, completely and thoroughly bored. It was just scene after scene of women talking about either wanting to be with the other, or why they don't want to be with them. There was just no real point to it all. If the show featured some crackling dialogue, or at least even some wit, the show may have developed some charm, but instead its just a big bland mess. One of the infuriating aspects this show has (and the majority of TV shows are guilty of this same problem) is that all of the characters seem to have extrodinarily unique and interesting professions. Art buyer, journalist, chef for a swanky resturant, etc. Don't people just work mundane jobs in offices anymore? There are a few good points about the show however. All is not completely lost. The trick is to turn the volume off. The casting is great. Mia Kershner and Jennifer Beals lead a cast of what seems like a competent actresses, with supporting actresses like Pam Grier. It's a cool and good looking cast. And the cinematography is good looking as well. It's one of the nicest looking drama series I've seen in years. It's stunning to watch at times. It's obvious that The L Word will build a loyal audience of viewers. I'm sure there'll be a vocal support from the 'lesbian community', as well as critical support for the series. It's just a shame that the show has such little depth to it. I recognise the irony in saying this about a lesbian drama, but what the show needs is some meat.

I always thought we lived in a sensible society. Apparently this is not so. Over the last month, we've seen how the Americans have over-reacted to the lame Janet Jackson breast flash at the Super Bowl. They've attacked her for revealing her breast, as heaven knows how many impressionable children may have seen it. Since then, anything that has the slightest scent of sexuality, profanity, or even a glimpse of nudity has been re-edited and repackaged to appease the morality of the country's fine citizens. Don't worry though, you can still watch people get stabbed, killed, and blown up. In Australia, we do things a little differently. I like to think that we're less reactionary and take things more in our stride. If there's a bit of nudity at a football game (be it a streaker, or whomever), it'll be met with some cheering, and if it's a female, any television cameras will stick with it for as long as possible. And why? Because it's not a big deal. The novelty value is high, and we're generally laid back, sensible folk. As sensible people, when it comes to the media, we've established a code to ensure that adults are free to see whatever they'd so choose. And so we have a film classification system designed to guide consenting adults through content that may or may not be appealing to them. This same classification system is also designed to prevent minors from seeing films that aren't suitable for them. And I'm cool with this. I generally feel that the Office of Film and Literature Classification do a good job in this regard. What I do have an issue with them is this: They are an organization that are repeatedly influenced by very small interest groups from the moral right. Films that have been banned recently after the OFLC recieved no more than three complaints. And so, I present you with this article from urlLink UrbanCinefile : ANOTHER FILM BAN LOOMS AS MINORITY EXERTS POWER Gaspar Noes R rated Irresistable, starring Monica Bellucci and Vincent Cassel, may be banned next week (March 29, 2004) by the Classification Review Board after complaints from both the Australian Family Association and Rev Fred Nile, who has written to the Federal Attorney General. What on earth were these people doing watching such a film? Didnt they see the R rating, asks Andrew L. Urban. The whole point of a film classification system is to advise consumers, and thus avoid the pathetically paternalistic social regimentation censorship represents. If the Review board submits to this minority pressure it will be repeating its clumsy acceptance of minority power demonstrated with the last refusal of classification in the controversial case of Baise Moi last year. As I wrote at the time, Baise Moi didnt offend the community enough to justify its eventual RC (Refused Classification). In correspondence with the Attorney Generals office, I was able to ascertain that of 419 letters regarding Baise Moi, "approximately 161 were opposed to the film and either sought a review of the Classification Board's decision, or were supportive of the Attorney-General's request for a review, or were in favour of the Review Board's RC (refused classification) decision. But only 27 indicated that they had SEEN the film and of those, THREE were opposed to the film." Just to reiterate the last point: of the 27 letter writers whod actually seen Baise Moi, only three were "opposed" to the film being released - and it isnt explained why they went to see it anyway, unless it was just to file a complaint. The film was rated R with the following warnings: strong sexual violence, high level violence, actual sex, adult themes. And yet some 50,000 people had seen it in its commercial release prior to the ban being imposed. The current case of Irreversible is similar, in that the film has been in release since mid February and the only complaints about it offending anybody have come from people who are professional offendees, not the general public. Since when do such minority views have more weight than the majority view? "We will obviously be defending this film", said Irreversible distributor Accent Film Entertainments Acquisition Manager Dean OFlaherty. "It is not just the film we are in the position of defending, and this is not just about banning one film, this is about an attack on freedom of speech and freedom of artistic expression". "While we acknowledge the topical nature of the film in light of recent high-profile allegations of sexual violence, Irreversible depicts the horrific consequences of such violence", adds General Manager, George Papadopoulos. The film was unanimously passed by The Office of Film and Literature Classification prior to its release in February, with an R18+ rating. Here are some earlier examples of censorship, courtesy Keith Lofthouse, showing how community standards change and how ridiculous censorship is: In 1920, Ohio censors tried to ban the classic Treasure Island, for fear that it would lead children to piracy...The Marx Bros Monkey Business was banned in Ireland for fear that it would provoke the Irish to anarchy... The Bing Crosby film Going My Way was banned in some South American countries because the cleric wore a baseball cap...In 1979, The Muppet Movie was cut by the New Zealand censor on grounds of gratuitous violence...And in 1973, New Zealands censor said he would pass Australias Adventures Of Barry McKenzie if one cut was made... from beginning to end. And now for a lesson in history. The 70's were a desperate time for nerds and geeks. Star Wars was still several years away. Computers only existed in TV shows like The Time Tunnel, and even then they were no good for downloading pictures of asian schoolgirls. They Might Be Giants were still yet to discover that people liked plastic foreheads on their real heads. But worse than all of this: Star Trek had been cancelled. Along came Bjo Trimble and her damned letter writing campaign. Bjo gathered up a gaggle of nerds to write in support of getting Star Trek back on the air. They were successful, which led to a proposed Star Trek 2 series, but instead morphed into the feature films, which begat The Next Generation, which begat several other Trek series of middling quality. Thankfully it also begat 7 of 9, of whom I'm sure we all agree was damn hot. While I actually don't mind Star Trek, Bjo deserves a very special place in TV hell (next to whomever greenlit Joe Millionaire ). As a result of Bjo's success, she's spawned imitators. A couple of years ago, the sci-fi series Roswell was cancelled. A campaign from fans sending tobasco bottles got the show back in production. And so, with two successes under their belt, it seems now when any TV show is cancelled, nerds commence their letter campaigns to get the attention of the world at large. Often, however, when a show is cancelled, it's doing the world a favour. Case in point: Tarzan. Last year an abysmal teen drama appeared on The WB featuring Tarzan in the city, doing stuff. The show was truly inspidly lame and I never bothered watching past the first 10 minutes to find out exactly what the show was about. It seems the entire viewership of the series (all five of them) must have loved the series, as they started a fairly intensive campaign to get the show back on the air. The world at large simply laughed at the dweebs. And rightfully so. The cancellation of Tarzan was a positive move, and thumbs its nose at those who think a letter writing campaign can save a TV show. Which brings me to the letter writing campaign I've opted to support. See, we here at Televised Revolution don't believe in lending our support to anything, unless it involves bringing something down. In this case, the West Wing. The West Wing spent four seasons as the most tightly written television show on the air, with dialogue that crackled with every syllabel. That is, until it's auteurist writer Aaron Sorkin was taken off the show by Warner Bros, and instead replaced by John "ER" Wells and his writing team. The show has nose dived into the most painful hour on television. A shadow of its former self. And so its begat http://dontsaveourshow.org/ An online campaign to cancel a television series. Finally a campaign I can support.

I'll admit it. I can be a cheap man at times. It's not that I don't want to spend my money. It's more that I'm interested in stretching it out as far as possible. Why buy a DVD or CD at full price, when if you shop around a little, you can generally get it a little cheaper? I like to stretch out the almighty dollar so that I can waste my money on more stuff. And so I'm looking at the website for the Buffy Down Under Convention. It's a two-day event with special guest urlLink James Masters , who plays Spike on Buffy, and now Angel. I've never been to a Buffy convention before, but I'd assume they're similar in nature to most fan conventions. You get one of the lesser stars from the show as a guest, with local nerds giving symposiums on assorted nerd-related issues. Local vendors (usually comic book stores and the ilk) sell their wares. Some of the nerds pick up and take home other nerds for the night, continuing their relationship for months over urlLink IRC , despite living just 2-3 suburbs away. For this, I'd expect to pay something in the range of $60-90 for the 2-day pass. And even then that's being generous. $240. I'm in shock. As I see it, there are two main expenses involved in holding an event like this: a location, and paying James Masters to come out for the event. I'd imagine you could get a couple of hundred fanboys to pony up the cash for an event like this, but how can they realistically charge $240? Is this just me being a tight-ass? Or is it a big waste of money? Last night I went and saw urlLink Kenny Kramer . Kramer of course being the inspiration for the wacky neighbor 'Kramer' on Seinfeld. Kenny was fairly amusing. He told some anecdotes about Jerry Seinfeld and Larry David?s lives before the Seinfeld series was created, showed a few videos, and played a trivia game with the audience of about 250 people. For this, I paid a concession rate of $30. Full-priced tickets were $37.50. He's an international guest the same as James Masters, and yet approximately $210 cheaper. How exactly does this work? I considered for a moment that they're potentially celebrities of different stature. I mean, come on, Masters is a very pretty man who appears weekly on a television series with a dedicated fan-base. But then I considered Kramer. I'd wager there's very few people who watch Seinfeld with any regularity wouldn't know that Kramer has a real life counterpart. Seinfeld was one of televisions highest watched series across the globe. And I'm positive that Kenny Kramer has given just as many, if not more, interviews and public speaking engagements as Masters. For the $240 that I could pay to go see James Masters, I could go see Kenny Kramer, hire a prostitute (I have one as an MSN buddy, and she assures me that it'd cost no more than $150 on a weeknight), and have enough money left over for pizza and a few DVD's.

And so, watch as I begin a descent into nerd country and discuss briefly Star Trek and it's complete inability to rock out. I've discussed this with people before, so if you've had the misfortune to hear my rant on this, feel free to tune out. If you're one of the many who've had to listen to my theological beliefs on why I won't eat seafood, you'd know better than to listen to me rant twice on one issue. It'd make your head hurt. That said, Star Trek, and why it will never get groovy with the rock the kids are listening to. Anytime I tune in to watch some Trek and they discuss music in any form, they're always listening to a classical composition of sorts. Beethoven seems to be a popular choice among the captains of Starfleet. Sitting back, pouring a glass of red wine, and listening to the piano and feeling rather mellow. And this is supposed to be our vision of the future of humanity? Sure, I dig me the classical music. But, variety is the spice of life spaceboys, and just listening to classical doesn't cut it. Why can't Captain Jean Luc Piccard put on some jazz music, or in the very least rock out with The Rolling Stones. Heck, they're in the future, listening to The Kings of Leon would be considered to be old-fashioned music (though, in many ways, that's the case now). In having seen what could potentially be several hundred hours worth of Star Trek over my life, I can only thing of two instances in which we heard some modern music. The first was in the Eighth Trek film FIRST CONTACT where one of the characters is listening to Steppenwolf's Magic Carpet Ride. While it was nice to hear some actual beats coming from the TV set, it's a shame the films producers couldn't at least have them listening to something a bit more current. But hey, baby steps. It's the second example that I feel says more about Star Trek in general than any other Star Trek scene in the history of the franchise. There's a scene in the film Star Trek 4 (The Voyage Home) where Captain Kirk and Mister Spock are riding a bus in mid-80's San Francisco. They encounter a punk-rocker on the bus listening to a boom box which is too loud and distresses the other people on the bus. Spock gives the punk a Vulcan nerve pinch, thereby sedating the kid, and turns off the music. And so the one time that Trek actually explores counter culture, it not only mocks it by acting as though it's a menace to the other decent god-fearing folk around, but Spock goes as far as to turn it completely off. If that doesn't say it all about the series, what does? Star Trek is suffering diminishing ratings and it's current series ENTERPRISE is in serious danger of cancellation. The problem as most people see it, is that the show refuses to evolve and actually explore new aspects of life. With our world facing such uncertainty these days, Star Trek would be the perfect venue to explore (through metaphor, as is its way) not only the current political climate (terrorism, globalisation, etc), but also to explore the changes in our daily society (homosexuality, the changes in the family unit, toe socks). Instead, it seems content to be stuck in its old ways of listening to Mozart and pouring the fine red.

Eco's concept of the Model Reader suggests that seminal to the creation of any text is an image of the work's ideal reader. This image is encoded within the text, in the way that it presents and restricts knowledge and the connections between signifier and signified it asks its reader to accept. This reader is not only contained within the text but enabled by the way the text presents itself to a reader and similarly shaped by the way a reader comes to a text. Moving to consider television specifically we can see this notion parallelled in Hartley's conception of television as a fundamentally pedocratic regime. Television appeals to the irresponsible and playful attitudes of its audience. In doing so, television likewise encourages its reader to approach it as such and find in television an approach to the world bound on ideas of enjoyment. Television's pedocratic regime does not treat its audience as childlike, but rather that television trains its audience in how to see it, how to respond to it and how to behave like an audience. Television further is relaint on the audience to come to it - free and consumed within the domestic sphere television has no hold over its audience beyond providing the audience with reasons to engage in the community it creates. As such, I am surprised when television is disrespectful towards its audience. Poor production values, patronising advertising and loosely constructed programming reflects a view of the audience. If TV is happy to turn out such product, then surely the audience could rightfully be expected to respond in a slipshod fashion, as it did with programs such as Marshall Law , Above the Law , Witness and The Resort and even Scott Cain. I have a long standing belief that no movie should be over 90 minutes long. I'll allow 100 minutes if it is an epic. I feel this is fair. If I'm going to pay my $10 admission in to see a film, who are you to dictate that I devote any longer than 90 minutes to a film? And so this brings me to last nights viewing Troy. Now, the film took close to three hours to tell. Now try asking me what I remember from the film. The answer lies with a couple of sword fights, and at the end they wheeled a big-ass horse into Troy. It was at this point some people actually gasped with suprise. Stupid people are breeding and we can't stop them. So, in the 180-odd minutes worth of film, I've walked away with very little recollection of what I saw. All I can say was that I wasn't bored. Well, not exactly. I wasn't exactly inspired either. And this, I feel, is the greatest shame of the movie. There's a wealth of material to be mined from the writings of Homer. And instead, all we're given is a tale that is an attempt to bring the audience a film best described as Gladiator meets Lord of The Rings. Try watching the battles in front of the city of Troy and tell me honestly that you weren't reminded heavily of the third Lord of The Rings film. It was pissweak. On top of that, we were given the exact same blurry computer generated crowd shots that made the LOTR films so uninteresting to watch at times. Contrast this against the other film I watched last night Hero (A film more than a little reminiscent of Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon), and the viewer can see what a vast difference can be made when you use real people for large crowd shots. Sure, 20,000 extras cost a fair amount of cash, but shooting 2,000 of them in such a way that the audience can use their imagination is surely preferable than being taken completely out of the film due to shoddy effects. And then there's the musical score. I liked it better when I saw Gladiator. To summarise: Long films make me sleepy. Films that don't really have any depth or much of a story stretched out over 3 hours make me sleepy and angered. The chick who played Helen of Troy was completely hot. Maximus could have kicked all of their arses. Troy gets two stars Helen of Troy gets five stars all the way.

Surprise, surprise urlLink Moore's 'Fahrenheit 9/11' to be released Miramax Films says it has reached a deal with its owners, Walt Disney, allowing it to find a new distributor for director Michael Moore's controversial new documentary Fahrenheit 9/11, which Disney refused to distribute. "We are very happy that Disney has agreed to sell Fahrenheit 911 to Bob and Harvey," Miramax spokesman Matthew Hiltzik said in a statement, referring to Miramax co-chiefs Harvey and Bob Weinstein. Under the agreement, the Weinstein brothers would acquire the rights to the film that chronicles America's response to the September 11 attacks and looks at links between the family of US President George W Bush and prominent Saudis, including the family of Osama bin Laden. Doesn't surprise me at all that this film has been sold on to another distributor. After the Oscar and Moore's recent campaign it was inevitable that this film would find another Nth American distributor. This statement confirms my cynicism about the entire fiasco however: Disney's decision, which it said it had made as long as one year ago, spurred headlines last week when Moore, the film-maker behind 2002's Oscar-winning Bowling for Columbine, went public with it. I don't mind Moore, I think he is a necessary force in the US particularly. I do however sometimes wonder if he is no more than a famewhore of a different constitution, especially given the sometimes inaccurate events some can find in his films (particularly Bowling... ). Every piece of research is always prone to disputation and the sourcing of alternative evidence and opinions (see the intellectual politicing that emerged from Blood on the Wattle etc). What I find interesting about Moore is that he does not tend to refute claims levelled against his films. This is a model that worked well for The Awful Truth which I always saw as more consciousness raising (or concept framing as the urlLink Kettering Foundation calls it) than anything else. I think documentaries have a responsibility to do more than merely raise issues however.
