Children's TV - aesthetic musings As I am sometimes want to do on a Saturday morning, this morning I woke up to children's television. Thanks to legislation, original children's programming is one of the things this nation's television system does best. I certainly enjoyed catching the first episode of Ten's urlLink The Legacy of the Silver Shadow this morning. Being as production was completed in 2002 I've probably already missed the entire series first time around but anyway, I caught it this morning. On the face of it, it had everything good children's fantasy drama should - a multi-ethnic cast, overacting 11 year olds, clunky scenes at 'school' and a completely untenable premise that perpetuates the autonomy of said overacting 11 year olds by absenting their parents from the text, leaving them free to cavort around the city at all hours of the afternoon. I loved it. It's not quite as engaging as Short Cuts but it's probably a step above Pig's Breakfast . The story goes that our appropriately diverse motley bunch of students, computer geek Campbell, overacting young driving obsessed Gretel, feisty team leader Alex and Josh, the mostly muscle male lead stumble across the secret lair of dead super hero The Silver Shadow, a Gigantor-like fellow who used to fight crime art deco style in the 1950s. Before he died Silver Shadow conveniently recorded his brain onto a computer (how?) and left it as an AI version of himself, charged to get together a new team of crime fighters should his old enemy, The Crab, come back to terrorise the city. Living Australian legend urlLink Bud Tingwell is in there somehow. I didn't quite catch it but I think he's bankrolling The Crab and 'cause this is a children's series, he's enlisted the services of his niece Fiona into his plan and that somehow involves her dressing up in The Crab's costume (that odd red outfit) and giving the kids trouble in her Corvette. It's worth pointing out here two things before I go any further. Firstly, the production design fluctuates between kickarse (the Silver Shadow costume itself) to piss poor (those bizarre grey outfits the team are wearing??). Secondly, Fiona can't drive the Corvette. Everytime she opens the door the car says "Welcome to your self-driving transport vehicle, where would you like to go?" which usually throws Fiona into a fit as she yells at it to "just drive"; urlLink Knight Rider 2000 it ain't. So through some convoluted plot the kids end up coming face to face with Fiona. Josh gets into his Silver Shadow outfit and gets is rump trumped by her crab powers. The scene was standard stock Mighty Morphin' Power Rangers - two costumed buffoons belting crap out of each other in the name of children's entertainment. When the urlLink Power Rangers did it, it was an homage to old Japanese monster flicks. Through some magic the bad guys grew the size of buildings and many cardboard cities that bore absolutely no relation to the rest of the sets we'd seen that episode were crashed and destroyed. Watching Crab-Fiona belt the crap out of Silver Shadow-Josh the little-doers down at Darestar Pty Ltd and Ponderosa Productions Pty Ltd just didn't seem able to recapture that costumed buffoon magic. They shot the same sort of setups used in Power Rangers, we had multiple retakes of swinging round house kicks and the obligatory waving of robot arms as Silver Shadow copped a whopping blow to the chest but I just didn't believe it. It looked too clean. I remembered a lesson I'd learnt years ago watching urlLink Dune , it is a skill to direct an action sequence. Lynch's adaptation of Herbert's novel is sweeping, missing somewhat some of the central ironies of the novel in favour of telling the story of a people finding their messiah. As intellectually stunning as his direction in something like Blue Velvet is, and this is apparent in some of the early internal scenes in the house of Atreidies, Lynch fails to capture the epic sweep needed to convey broad action sequences. Cobbled by their close fitting, Batman -esque still suits (costume designer Bob Ringwood went on to design Keaton's rubber masterpiece), this wily band of Fremen fail to look menacing as they charge down dunes. The lack of sweeping cinematics let down the action sequences. The same seems to be the case with Silver Shadow . It takes more than just clever editing, quirky angles and collapsing cardboard boxes to make action scenes convey action; the blocking needs to work, the characters need to look imposing, not just upon each other but as masters of their domain. Moreover, Silver Shadow stands as another example of the way that digital technologies have killed television. Granted, with DV you can shoot broadcast quality straight out of the box but you don't get the depth and texture film offers. Compare Lynch's Dune with the Sci-Fi Channel's 2001 urlLink remake . The crispness of the images in Silver Shadow 's "action" scenes took away from the illusion of power individual shots of fists and hands can evoke. The lighting was too high key, even though it was shot outside and much reflected and ambient light was used. These shots had no soul. "But DV is empowering, it allows people to make high quality TV on lower budgets" Sit down you film geek. DV allows less funding to be given to production companies, for more to be demanded for less. And this is evident in the fact that networks still don't cough up all the dough for such a production. But that's an argument about profit margins that can wait for another day. On Gully's scale I give this program 6 Hasselhoffs. I'd be happy to catch it next weekend but I won't be making sure I'm sober enough to watch it. I mean it's hardly urlLink The Worst Witch , the urlLink TV version of which I thoroughly recommend with a cup of strong black coffee as a hang-over cure on a Sunday morning.

Connecting the cultural cringe to here Appropriately as this is my first article for televised revolution it touches on two of the most endearing elements in my life - women and television. Its been a week filled with ex-girlfriends, with one former-Ms Gully arriving from Fish Ponds, Bristol, UK, one sending me random emails from Germany, and one turning 25. But thats mostly an aside. Collecting the first from the architectural masterpiece that is urlLink BrisVegas International Airport I was introduced to former-Ms Gullys New Beau, which was when the fun really began. Time and fondness made the new-beau/old-beau awkwardness but perfunctory and once that seemingly required hurdle was surmounted discussion moved onto more important topics. As former-Ms Gully and I sized up the shifts in our respective cultural caches (she still doesnt understand what happened in the final season of Buffy but does agree with me that Sidneys costumes have gone downhill in the latest season of Alias ), New Beau announced hes looking forward to using his four weeks in Australia as an opportunity to immerse myself in Australian television. Former-Ms Gully voiced her disdain for Australian television, I was forced to face my own internal cringing at the thought of the television this international visitor would be considering our own. News broadcasts and petty moral panic inducing tabloid journals aside, what is the state of our television he would be judging us by? Would immersing himself in Australian television involve repeats of The Simpsons , multiple Law and Order franchises and the Toni Pearon lead crime against decency that is Australias Funniest Home Videos ? As I got home and flicked on the box I suffered through quality Australian infomercial programming such as Bright Ideas and urlLink Lets Do It before the Bombers came on to beat the Swans. Is this the Australian television well be judged on? Is that the image of here hell take back with him? Reflecting back over the conversation however I noticed that the programs wed discussed were from a there that didnt belong to either of us. Absenting a brief sojourn past urlLink Im Peter Andre Get Me Out Of Here , all the television we were trading notes on were products of the illustrious Home of the Brave. On the face of it this does not bother me; as much as I loved Tales of the South Seas , I maintain a great and unashamed fondness for television from Schwarzeneggers heartland. For former-Ms Gully however, the high amount of American programming makes the idea was watching television in Australia either reductive or counter productive. Or maybe both. What became evident however is that New Beau was excited about watching television here. Regardless of where it comes from, its about experiencing it within the Australian cultural context. Television is about connecting people here with events there urlLink . For New Beau, as a citizen from elsewhere his desire to immerse himself in Australian television bespeaks a want to connect with the here by participating in the ritual of watching television in the rhythm of Australia. Every national television system is built around assumptions about the rhythms of daily life, and television itself tracks the ebbs and flows of Australian daily life. This seems an issue often subjugated in discussions about what it is that defines national television product. This is not to say we should sign away future rights to protect industry as the current Free-Trade-Agreement seems to require us to do. Rather, I think it is time we broadened our understanding of what constitutes Australian television culture beyond urlLink Bonanza with Tampons (thankyou finbar).

I realise that these words may sting, and even hurt you. And the thought of that is enough to destroy my emotional fabric. But we have to work through it. We're just not the same people we once were. Thank you for the good times we've shared together. I think in our hearts that we both knew that our futures were never meant to be shared. With all my love Daniel

MOUNTAIN LEAVES ME COLD In August, the eyes of the world will be transfixed on the television watching the telecast of the urlLink 2004 Olympic Games in Athens. Every set of eyes but mine. You see, I'm one of those rare species of people who not only doesn't enjoy watching sports, but I also tend to ignore the Olympic Games. All of that said, there is one sporting event that does catch me in its grip. The urlLink Winter Olympic Games . It's one of the few opportunities given to be able to watch winter sports on the television. There's just something about the beauty and majesty of the landscape, combined with the skill and passion of the athletes competing in snow and on ice. It's breathtaking to watch and experience. Other than the Olympics, the only other place to catch this action is while watching extreme sports shows featuring urlLink snowboarding . But now, there's also the new WB series The Mountain. Or at least, it could have been. So, what's it about? Essentially, it's a family drama that focuses on two twenty-something brothers, their young teenage sister, and their inattentive mother (a philantropist and former Winter Olympic gold medalist). The siblings grandfather dies and leaves the mountain resort they all live at to the oldest sibling: the black sheep of the family who abandoned them all to pursue a life that seemingly involves car racing. Can he keep the family together, while also keeping the urlLink resort viable? For the sake of the viewing audience, I certainly hope not. Who's in the darn thing? Welcome to one of the biggest faults with the series. Heading up the cast is the uninteresting Oliver Hudson, the son of Goldie Hawn and presumably Kate Hudsons brother. The dude is almost watchable in this, but at times it's almost as if he is Steven Webbers younger more attractive brother. Somewhat creepy really. Barbara Hershey plays the family's matrix. It's such a shame that she's such a bore to watch in almost every role she plays. Most notable is actress Tara Thompson, if only for her uncanny resemblance to Australian soap/teen sensation urlLink Delta Goodrem . And finally, former X-Files star Mitch Pileggi puts in an appearance as the shows bad guy, a real estate developed trying to get his hands on the resort. Loved the guy in the X-Files, but so far he's lacked charisma in practically every show he's been in since. What happens in the first episode? The grandfathers will is read out and annimosity develops between the brothers, with one of them getting entire control of the resort, while the other has spent his adult life actually running the place. Their sister has trouble coping with the loss of her grandfather, and so drinks a little and almost engages in sexual activity with a young man. Heavens, no. Not to fear, as by the end of the episode, everyone resolves their issues and they come out of it as a strong family unit. Is it any good? I didn't hate it at first. Sure, it wasn't very good, but there was nothing greatly objectionable about it. It has, however, left me with a truly horrid aftertaste. In thinking back on it, the show has no redeeming aspects. The casting was clunky, the dialogue was trite, and after watching the entire pilot, I'm still not entirely certain what the show will be about. The only concept I can see is the real estate developer attempting to snare the resort every episode. Because he's that eager and desperate for it (insert rolling eyes emoticon). Ho hum. Produced by Hollywoods very own Lucifer McG, the show should at least be able to rely on the stunningly beautiful background mountain ranges and some awesome photography involving the snowboarding daughter in the show. But instead, much of the action takes place indoors, with the snowboard photography being dull and lifeless. It's such a shame to see the shows one extrodinary positive aspect wasted completely. If the show is to succeed, it either needs to improve remarkably in the first few episodes of the series, or needs an excellent timeslot with a good lead-in. As it stands, I can't see many people eager to make the trip up The Mountain.

JJ FINDS HIMSELF The movie Cast Away made millions upon millions of dollars at the box office. Yet, it was never really part of the cultural zeitgeist. Sure, there were jokes about Tom Hanks friend Wilson (a volleyball), but they never exactly made it into a People Weekly 25 Hottest Couples list. And so, the new telly show by Alias creator JJ Abrams struck me as a little odd in concept. Similar ideas have been done countless times, so why do we need another take on a Lord Of The Flies-esque tale? But frankly, I'm glad they ran with the concept, because if this pilot is anything to go by, they have a corker of a series. I'm just hoping that the audience never gets.....LOST. So, what's it about? The concept can't get any simpler. A plane crashes on an island. The remaining passengers are all remarkably attractive and deal with the trauma of a crash while recognising the fact that they may not be found anytime soon. What is that huge creature stalking them, and why did that guy just shoot a polar bear? Who's In The Darn Thing? While there's no one specifically outstanding, it's one of those great ensemble casts with just a few disappointing folk littering the group. Heading the cast is Party of Fives Matthew Fox, a guy with a great TV presense that never really made it as big as pretty much everyone else in that cast. Which is a shame, because he really commands viewers attention here. He's lost his trademark 3-day facial hair (but I suspect this may be part of a custody battle with the dude in the recently cancelled series Wonderfalls). Lord of The Rings hobbit Domonic Monaghan is part of the cast as is TV great Terry O'Quinn sans his beautiful and perfect moustache. It's almost as if a conscious decision has been made to leave all signiature facial hair at home for the pilot. What Happens In The Crucial First Episode? Well, the plane goes down. Everyone yells and runs around for a bit. Matthew Fox saves some lives. The ex-Iraqi soldier fixes the transmission device, and they climb a mountain for help. And like Alias, it looks like we're in for a cliffhanger to end every episode. On the subject of Alias, should this show follow Alias' lead and actually allow its characters to radically change, and grow, and all sorts of other opportunities not allowed to TV characters generally, who's willing to bet that they might not necessarily stay on the island for the duration of the show? If they're not off the island by halfway through season two, I'd be remarkably suprised. Is It Any Good? Just try and stop me from raving about it. I enjoyed the heck out of the show and will be waiting with baited breath for it to continue on. The show has a few negative aspects. A hotheaded character who is there to antagonise the group is more annoying than a character 'the audience loves to hate'. And as much as I love seeing actor Daniel Dae Kim in shows, I don't know how far they can take his character as he doesn't speak any english. Although, maybe there's more to that than there seems to be.... This show, like Alias, is exactly what popcorn fun should be. It's a heck of a lot of fun, and it'd be criminal if audiences don't take to it.

Something I think about urlLink Wildside . Wildside is the sort of drama the ABC should be funding. I don't mean cop shows or serious dramas. Wildside was a program that was a little to 'edgy' to succeed on the commercial networks because of their inherent confidence problems and business approach to broadcasting. I think it is the ABCs role to make up the difference. Wildside conforms to what John Caldwell describes as televisuality - television where style is brought to the fore as a marker of quality. Max Headroom, Twin Peaks, the Sopranos and Sex and the City are all examples of Televisuality. It is often loss leader television and the rise of HBO as a place where televisuality is respected is part of an argument about shifts in television and the acknowledgment of style as a brand - the coming of what Rogers, Reeves and Epstein refer as TVIII - television not necessarily constrained by the broadcast form. But that's another argument... Thanks to the funding cuts, the ABC only has the funding to produce one high production drama series per annum, which seems counterproductive when balanced against the claims of the early 00s that the ABC should be measured against ratings success to justify its existence. The problem with the application of such a model is that the ABC is not rewarded for the production of successful programs, many of which it the ongoing production of which would come at the expense of new productions, and secondly, it makes the ABC nothing more than a govt funded commercial network. In such a position Aunty has no room to produce programs that are valuable, quality, or just plain good television (like Wildside) that would not be funded by commercial television because of the profit margin system in place. As Producer Steve Knapman suggests urlLink here , "They [the commercial networks] dont have enough true commercialism to be entrepreneurial about breaking ground on their own network." Now before we go on to say that the ABC shouldn't be dropping Govt - sorry I mean public funds into productions that only academics and a few geeks who talk about television on the internet will enjoy I would like to pint out that urlLink SLOU , one of the finest commercially successful dramas of late failed in its first season. Coming out of urlLink Big Brother in 2001 SLOU debuted to mediocre ratings (remember it was test screened to the housemates?). Ten needed an Australian drama hit with the cessation of their output deals in 1999, the wind up of their remaining product, challenges for their core audience from Seven and Nine, and the abomination that was Above the Law (which was a great show that was marketed badly - more on that another time). SLOU, the first major Sue Masters project after her high profile shift, needed to be a success for Ten. Ten gave SLOU an "oncore" screening, running the program over the summer of 01-02, right on the back of its original wind up and supported by their glossy "Summer of Love" campaign. This also meant the program ran pretty much straight into the second series in 02. The encore screening constructed SLOU as "the best program we all missed out on the first time", the audience got a second chance to sample the program, the 02 season was a success. Wildside likewise was a critical and passionately supported success. It's cancellation points to a questioning of the role of the ABC. What's wrong with the production of high quality drama that only a few people watch? Marginal audiences have been the speciality of the ABC since aggregation and equalisation in the 1980s. But the other question this raises, and this is a discourse present in this post itself, why does successful, commercial television have to be lowbrow?

SCHLAMME SETTLES FOR WEST WING: TNG I'm a rather jaded individual. Really, I'd rather not be, but everything tends to let me down. Especially the Adelaide Crows. Not that I really follow football, but I chalk that up to the fact that the team I "support" are pissweak. But I digress. My jaded attitude towards television has been only strengthened in the past by viewing TV crud like Family Matters and Dogs Head Bay. For every pure gem like The West Wing, comes along a 7th Heaven, or even a My Wife and Kids. It's enough to make me want to hurl my TV out onto the urlLink street . But I could never do that. I love the telly too much. I am very much its bitch. Sometimes, a television show will make such an impact on me that i'm flummoxed. How can this be? Something of quality on the telly? It can't be. Like people, there are some shows that are paving their way to greatness. One such show is urlLink Jack and Bobby . So, what's the deal? urlLink Jack and his younger brother urlLink Bobby are in high school. Their single-parent mother (almost a carbon copy of the mother from Almost Famous) is a university professor who has attempted to instill a sense of intelligence and greatness among her own boys. Especially the younger boy Bobby. What none of them realise just yet is that as they groom Bobby for adulthood, they're also grooming him to become a man that will take on the title of President of the United States. Who's In The Darn Thing? Christine Lahti (Chicago Hope) plays the central mother figure, with two newcomers in the roles of her children. John Slattery (Ed) also has a recurring role as a potential love interest for the Lahti. What Happens In the Crucial First Episode? Bobby's heading off for his first day in high school. Being a terminally wierd kid, he finds issues with peer group pressure and the desire to be accepted are stronger than thay had been in the past. Jack, meanwhile, has his eyes set on the new girl at school. Their mother comes to realise that she's smothered Bobby for years and it's now time for him to learn how to gain strength on his own, and so Jack takes on a significant role in helping him gain independence. The first step the family makes to assist Bobby: They buy their first TV set. Is It Any Good? Edited with glimpses into future leaders and political commentators discussing the impact of Bobby's life as President, and the path that led him towards it. While some people may see this as gimmicky and a tad hokey, it somewhat works for the show. Off putting to some, but it more than works for me. The casting is great, and the direction by former X-Files helmer David Nutter is spot-on. It'll be interesting to see how the show will develop, but unless the gods are on its side, I can't see it lasting more than two seasons. Instead, it'll join the ranks of the many other shows that TV nerds obsess over for not having a long enough lifespan.

JURY DECISION: GUILTY OF MAKING ME YAWN My final two years of high school are when I discovered love for the first time. It taught me the warmth and purity that one can feel in life. I'll never forget that first love. The way her beauty touched me in ways previously unimaginable. I was deeply smitten. You see, for it was in my senior years that I truly fell in love with television. Don't get me wrong, I'd experimented with TV in the past. My parents were open and accepting of my lifestyle choice. They felt it was healthy to allow me to watch TV and indulge in its warm glow. It was a love that took on several forms. Seinfeld, The X-Files, Denton, and the one that has probably had the greatest influence on my television habits since: Homicide: Life On The Street . Homicide was never my favourite show, and I don't think it ever could be. But while urlLink Seinfeld was the last gasp of air in the life of the traditional multi-camera sitcom genre, Homicide lay the foundations for the quality and depth that television would be able to achieve in the years to follow. While not the only quality show on the air, Homicide provided a gritty, mature, and crisp writing and style that would soon be taken aboard by the next wave of television auteurs. Homicide paved the way for US television to approach a similar grit and maturity that UK series had been handling on the airwaves for years. Much of the credit for Homicide lies with writer Tom Fontana. Since the cancellation of Homicide, urlLink Fontana has moved on to other series such as the Supurb series Oz (currently screening on SBS), and now has a new show hitting the air The Jury. Needless to say, based on my love of Homicide: Life on The Street, I was eager to see what the new show was like. While Homicide and Oz have done everything right, The Jury has done quite the opposite. So, what's the deal? It's quite simple. We follow the jury into the jurors room as they nut out the truth behind the trial they are witnessing. The audience watches them make up their minds, and as the urlLink jury foreman delivers their verdict in the courtroom. The final scene of the episode shows us what really happened and whether the jury made the right decision. Who's in the darn thing? Every week we have a new cast of jurors. Hopefully, based on this first episode, the casting director is fired. The dialogue, which stilted enough in its writing, sounds even worse out of the mouths of seemingly B grade actors. When an episode of a TV show revolves around a guest star, they can either make or break the show. While its fantastic to see a guest star run with a role completely and make it work beautifully, it can be irksome to see them fall flat. At least then we can focus on the regular cast to carry us through. Unfortunately this is 90% guest actors every week, and in the first episode, nobody's hitting any home runs. The regular cast includes Billy Burke (who stunk up the screen in the poorly written abusive father role at the beginning of 24's second season), the dude who played Warren in season six of Buffy, and finally (in a pretty clever bit of casting) is executive producer of the series (and well respected feature film director) urlLink Barry Levinson . What happens in the crucial first episode? Some ghetto kids are shooting at firecrackers on a rooftop with a semi-automatic. A kid in a neighbouring building is shot. But is the kid on arrest charges the guilty suspect? It's all very Law & Order really. Is it any good? It's a novel concept. Writer Tom Fontana has referred to it as the middle part of his trilogy (Homicide having dealt with the police and Oz dealing with the prison system). The problem with the show falls on two factors. The first is the guest stars. I've discussed this already, but if they really want to be able to sell the concept completely to viewers, they'll need great actors, as well as better dialogue for them. Obviously they're fighting the shows running time by trying to introduce as much characterisation as possible among the 12 jurors, while also dealing with analysing the case. I appreciate the difficulty in doing this, but they really do come off sounding very hackneyed. The second problem comes with the concept itself. Part of the excitement of any legal series or movie comes from the exciting courtroom scenes. The very nature of focussing on the jury goes against this. It's almost as if the concept is too clever to deal with on network TV. The discussions in the jury room deal heavily with ethics and analysis of information. By trying to jazz up the proceedings with forced characterisation (a necessity to stay on air on urlLink US network TV ), it has stripped the show of any real intellectual stimulation. That isn't to say the audiences won't eat this up in droves. I can quite easily see the CSI audience watching on eagerly to try to come up with the correct verdict. It's essentially a dramatic gameshow. Clearly, the show isn't quite for me. But I can certainly see it'll have its fans.

TV terrorism Here's a fascinating Sunday-morning-on-the-net discovery. urlLink Michael H gives us Rarely Seen Scenes, recording some obscura from American television history. On Nov. 22, 1987, video hackers managed to override the Chicago PBS station's broadcast of 'Dr. Who' for 90 seconds and replace it with a signal beamed from their secret location. Drunk with mad power, the dastardly duo also hacked into a major Chicago commercial station that night for a several moments. What did said hackers do with access to the eyes of millions? Well one of them dressed up in a urlLink Max Headroom mask and cavorted around before dropping his daks for his also masked partner to paddle his rear. Michael H seems a little disappointed with this effort, especially given the fact they had the broadcaster at their mercy. I don't see why. When you look at the other examples of TV terrorism he presents the anti-Aids protest on the CBS Evening News, Arsenio Hall offering a diatribe about gay-rights activists, Jerry Lewis' stalker and SNL's Conspiracy Theory Rock the best examples are the first and the last. The Max Headroom incursion and Conspiracy Theory Rock use the medium to comment, challenging producers and audience members to consider their status as producers and audience members. The other three are a hijacking of live events in ways that have little to do with television itself. They appear as incursions on the form of television. By contrast, the Max Headroom prank brings Max Headroom himself to television, moving the events of the fictional character out of the confines of it's designated narrative and slot and making it real. Max Headroom comments on media control; the irony of the program being that it is fiction, locked into the power structure of the mass media system it parodies. By making Max real and breaking into an actual broadcast the status of the media system as a gatekeeper of the airwaves is challenged, a point made only more poignant by the fact the attack featured seemingly senseless paddling. Pity they broke into Dr Who though. I like Dr Who. On the one hand there is an added layer of irony in the fact the terrorists disrupted a program not specifically designed for the American television system. On the other hand however, the scheduling environment in which programs are placed causes a reconstitution of the program to match the cultural environment. Yuri Lotman's theory of cultural translation suggests that as texts cross cultural boundaries between semiospheres (cultural spaces) they are re-written in the language of the new semiosphere, resulting not in a recreation of the original text but in the creation of a new version, changed by its status in the new cultural space. As such, the Dr Who that screens on American television does not bring carry the same constitution as the Dr Who that screens in the UK or Australia. Perhaps its not doubly ironic at all, but rather further evidences the role of media orgs as gatekeepers of broadcast systems?

WANKING THE AUDIENCE ALONG - TELEVISION'S IDENTITY CRISIS Big Brother company's latest plan: 'sperm race' TV Television producers were criticised yesterday over reports that they are developing a reality show in which men would compete for a chance to father a child and then take part in an on-air "sperm race". In the show, which has been mooted by the company that makes Channel 4's Big Brother, up to 1,000 men would attempt to convince a woman to pick them as the father of her first child by impressing her with their intelligence, sex appeal and fitness. A second sperm donor would be chosen on the basis of genetic compatibility, and the two finalists would then take part in the sperm race in which the insemination process could be filmed using new technology. Brighter Pictures, a subsidiary of Endemol, is considering making the programme, provisionally called Make Me a Mum. An Endemol spokesman said details about the show's contents were speculative. Life, an anti-abortion campaign group, said the show "sounds like prostitution". A spokesman said: "It's absolutely despicable. It's exploitation with no consideration for the child that may or may not be created. If the child learns that he or she was fathered, not out of love, but for the purposes of a TV programme, that's extremely psychologically damaging." Remy Blumenfeld, Brighter's creative director, told Broadcast magazine: "There's a tremendous amount of science to this show. It's completely fascinating. It's much more about the rule of science than the rules of attraction." Brighter Pictures attracted controversy with a previous show, for Sky One, called There's Something About Miriam in which a group of men competed for the affections of a woman, only to discover she was a transsexual. Yep, uhuh, okay. Not the first time children have been given away for money or entertainment and certainly not the first time money has been exchanged for sex. Is this really about the rule of science however? What is the point of the competition element? If the footage is compelling, and I for one would be interested to see the little Thorpies going for their lives, then film it. Make it a doco. All of which makes me think about the arguments Hartley puts forward in Popular Reality. Part of journalism's saving grace is the way in which it connects the domestic, home bound reader with broader issues in the public sphere. It allows them to make meanings by connecting their experience of the everyday with broader semiotic tools for meaning making. With the personalisation of politics produced by the feminisation of the public sphere and rise of identity politics, previously derided and feminised spheres such as fashion, gossip, celebrity and entertainment reporting have attained more significance. Cleo and Cosmo teach and should be understood as part of the new face of journalism. In the same sense reality television is a new educative force. Given such, the sort of comments I have made above about the producers being disingenuous about their intentions are on the one hand naive. Such suspicion is, I admit, produced by discourses I perpetuate about the value of certain forms of television. On the other hand however, I do think that such statements comment on a broader issue conventional broadcast television may be facing. With increasing fragmentation of both delivery and reception channels I suspect the audience (or parts of it at least) is getting restless with the treatment they have suffered at the hands of broadcasters. With the rise of alternative delivery channels, and increasingly it is a matter of alternative acquisition channels becoming available, the audience is finding itself in a greater position of power to choose what and how it wishes to engage with the network. Statements that something like this are mostly social scientific seem dangerous then as they raise the ire of cynicism. Most everyone in their lounge rooms realise this show is about watching a competition for baby jelly. That is where the excitement, the drama, will come from. Yes, it will reveal insights into the nature of love and the rules of attraction but I doubt if that will be the overarching discourse that frames the way the program is presented and delivered. Big Brother, in Australia at least, does not emphasise effectively in its delivery the fact that it is a social experiment 1 . Given such, it seems arrogant on the part of the broadcaster not to credit the audience with intelligence about the medium itself. It might be a case of trying to sex up the concept by hiding behind the auspices of pop-sociology, but I doubt it convinces the citizen-come-audience-member. What would be refreshing would be television acknowledging its own status. urlLink 1. RECOVERING LOSS LEADER TELEVISION Seeing what I suspect is an aging urlLink Dylan Lewis on the trailer for urlLink Mark Trevorrow's urlLink The Way We Were got me thinking about urlLink Recovery , and once again my musings about youth television have brought me back to considering the role of the national broadcaster. urlLink Recovery was certainly a product of its time, which is why it wouldn't be the same now if it was to be resurrected or re-imagined in whatever form. It did come however at the tail end of a time when the ABC invested resources and energy in attracting an audience aged 16-24. As the budget cuts have constrained the broadcaster since, this audience has fallen unserviced and that point is acknowledged by the ABC itself, which is a market leader in children's and tween entertainment, scores reasonably with an audience in their 'middle years' and does particularly well with the Blue Rinse set. Recovery, along with Race around the World, Heartbreak High and to a lesser extent Attitude (which ultimately became a programme adults watched in the hope of gaining an 'insight' into their teenaged children) was the end of a line of youth directed programming at the ABC, the cessation of which was a product of a need to centralise resources and the resounding success of Triple J throughout the 1990s. It seems with the death of these programs ABC TV stopped attempting to compete in the loss leading youth market and instead resigned itself that that was the domain of ABC radio (JJJ). Since, ABC TV produced programs which have attracted youth have been few and far between, contained in the success of more broadly targeted programs such as GNW, The Fat and The Glass House. The Fly TV development was an attempt to do once again on television, the sort of thing JJJ did on the radio. Of course, the fear of new television developments that is used to justify the raping of the ABC in this country saw money diverted elsewhere when the channel was not an immediate success. This decision was, in my personal view, one that disregards the history of youth television as a site for innovation in television and part of the government's more broader mismanagement of the development of digital television as a medium. More recent programming such as Cath and Kim has drawn a youth audience to the broadcaster however, for the most part, the ABC has chosen to draw youth to the service through radio. Economically this decision makes some sense, and I'm not going to dispute it outright because, despite it's current misgivings, Triple J has been an important asset to youth culture generally. What concerns me however is that with the cessation of youth programming on the ABC a core place for innovation in television is demolished. Part of the hope for Fly was that it could become such a place, following in the steps of community radio and television in this sense as a ground where new talent could get a sample and a bit of experience in order to launch them into the mainstream. However more broadly, the decline of youth programming leaves televisoin without a key site for the loss-leader programs youth TV slots have typically provided. Double the Fist and Pizza are good examples - like them or loathe them, they are innovations in how to make low-budget television. Crank Yankers and Southpark similarly. Further evidence for this role is found in the experience of cable roll out across Europe, where sport drove cable uptake and music broadcasting (to a degree) the development of programming. Similarly, the innovations MTV brought to the American market (and eventually the world) were in part attributable to the fact they were operating under a profit model that did not require mainstream success. It seems to me with the national youth broadcaster abandoning to some extent youth programming, the predominant place for innovation in Australian free-to-air television has become Network Ten. It follows a similar model to Fox in the US, a model who's roots ultimately lie in cable broadcasting, and by targeting an audience constructed to be receptive to new ideas, it becomes a key space for the innovation of Australian television. Big Brother, Australian Idol, The X-Files, Rove, GNW, and even Bread are televisual innovations. Granted none are essentially the product of Ten themselves, but Ten is the place for them to appear because it has its finger on the youth button. As much as CSI and 24 are innovative also, Ten has been the Network which has reaped the most financial rewards from innovations in programming. While this last point may seem to contradict my earlier arguments that youth television is principally loss-leader TV, Ten's financial success has come as much on the back of its low overheads and constricted running costs as it has its advertiser success. The difficulty with this is that it leaves Australia as a site which is not so much open to innovation as it is to adopting the innovations of others. If we were to remove the necessity for the ABC to justify its funding in terms of ratings measurements and instead render its success in terms of meeting its charter obligations, perhaps innovative youth television could return to the ABC as a valuable servicing of the needs of an audience segment. Because as much as Ten sports youth television, the youth programming it carries is programming designed to answer to a psychographic conception of 'youth' rather than a demographic one. Of course, removing the necessity for the ABC to quantify its performance in terms understandable by the entire industry leaves us with the age old problem of determining how it is meeting its charter obligations. All of which I think is about either reconceptualising the funding model provided to the ABC (which will never happen) or reconceptualising the understanding of public broadcasting. Of course, this discussion, which I suspect loses it's way a little towards the end, does nothing to consider the state of play over at urlLink Channel [V] which deserves some consideration as a successful site for youth television on Australian Tele. The constitution of V is much like JJJ with pictures and herein lies some of its own success. It also does not move to consider the greater developments in youth programming, namely the emergence of the one hour teen drama as the core genre that has embodied youth TV throughout the 1990s. The Teen Drama is innovative television, often assuming a role as loss-leading - as much as Twin Peaks and The X-Files are televisual entities, so too Buffy the Vampire Slayer and Dawson's Creek have brought innovations of form through an emphasis on style to the television screen. Similarly, in considering loss-leader television throught the late 90s, one needs to look to HBO branded product such as Oz, The Sopranos and Sex and the City, as well as Push, Nevada and the adventure game exemplars such as Survivor and The Amazing Race. Maybe more about them another time.

TELLY COMPAS POINTS NORTH And so, as my plane took to the heavens, I found myself looking whistfully out the window, just like Harper at the end of Angels in America. With a sigh, I began to think about the fact I was going home. To the familiar. To the ground I'd treaded many times before. It was much the same feeling I got when watching the new FOX series North Shore. While it was watchable, it felt far too familiar to be interesting. Like getting home from the airport and entering a musty house, you just want to open up some windows to freshen the place up a little. So, what's it about? Welcome to North Shore. A ritzy hotel resort on an island in Hawaii. We follow the staff (a bar tender, poolboy, waitress, and the shows leads of whom are presumably working as resort managers) as they find themselves involved in the lives of the patrons at the resort. I much prefered the series when it was called The Love Boat. Who's in the darn thing? Seemingly half the cast of Baywatch Hawaii, so already we know that we're going to be reaching new heights of televised greatness. Of note to audiences are former Baywatch actress Brooke Burke, and character actor urlLink James Remar . A perculiar aspect to the series is that one of the shows producers is listed as Chris Brancato, a producer primarily known for working with genre series like Tru Calling and First Wave. What happens in the first episode? The somewhat uninteresting and verging on bland lead male actor is quite happy with his life until the day his ex-girlfriend (Brooke Burke) rocks up to share his job with him. Meanwhile, he finds himself being used by the PR agent of a foxy tennis sensation staying at the resort. In other happenings, the pool boy is accused of sexually interfering with a 15 year old patron. By the end, everyone faces an emotional realisation and leaves the hotel feeling better about their lives. But is it any good? It'll likely get a season or two out of production, but it's no more involving than a standard Aaron Spelling piece of trash. The Hawaii setting is its greatest asset, but is simply not being used to its full potential. It's beautiful as hell to look at, but when you consider the way the state was used as a location in the recent film Blue Crush, as well as the TV series The Byrds of Paradise, disappointment seeps in. In Blue Crush & Byrds, Hawaii's people and culture played an integral part of visual flavour of the series. Instead, North Shore may as well just be set on a resort in LA somewhere. It's simply scantily dressed US whiteys as far as the eye can see. North Shore is easy viewing. But at the same time it's very disposable. I can't see there'd be many people buying DVD box sets in a few years.
